title: ExcelParentheses

metadata.description: Learn about ExcelParentheses with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title:
Excel
Parentheses

Parentheses
Parentheses
content_sections.content:
()
is used to change the order of an operation.
Using parentheses makes Excel do the calculation for the numbers inside the parentheses first, before calculating the rest of the formula.
Parentheses are added by typing
()
on both sides of numbers, like
(1+2)
.

content_sections.title: No parentheses
content_sections.content:
=10+5*2
The result is
20
because it calculates (
10+10
)

content_sections.title: With parentheses
content_sections.content:
=(10+5)*2
The result is
30
because it calculates
(15)*2
Formulas can have groups of parentheses.
=(10+5)+(2*4)+(4/2)
Note:
Cells can be used as values in the formulas inside parentheses, like
=(A1+A2)*B5
. We have used manual entries in our examples to keep things simple.
Let's have a look at some real examples in Excel.
Without Parentheses
The result is
17
, the calculation is
2+15
. It uses
15
because
3*5=15
.
With One Parentheses
The result is
25
, the calculation is
5*5
. It uses
5
because it has calculated numbers inside the parentheses
(2+3)=5
first.
With Many Parentheses
The result is
17
, the calculation is
5+8+4
. The numbers inside the parentheses are calculated first.
Nesting Parentheses
When using more advanced formulas you may need to nest parentheses. You can look at this like an onion, which has many layers. Excel will calculate the numbers inside the parentheses first, layer by layer, starting with the inner layer.

content_sections.title: Example no nesting
content_sections.content:
=2*2+3*4+5*5*2
It calculates the values flat as you would do with a calculator.

content_sections.title: Example nesting
content_sections.content:
=((2*2)+(3*4)+(5*5))*2
Let's break it down and explain.
Nesting creates layers like an onion. You can have many layers. This example uses two, the inner and outer layers.
It starts with calculating the numbers in the inner layer:
=((2*2)+(3*4)+(5*5))*2
=((4)+(12)+25))*2

content_sections.title: Calculates the inner layer
content_sections.content:
=(41)*2
Calculates the outer layer
82
Chapter Summary
Parentheses can be used to change the order of an operation. The numbers inside the parentheses gets calculated first. A formula can have sets of parentheses. More advanced formulas can use nesting to create layers of operations, like an onion. It calculates the inner layer first, then the

summary: This tutorial covers ExcelParentheses concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use ExcelParentheses effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of ExcelParentheses and how to apply it in your projects.
